name: Malay Fish Owl
description: Ketupas resemble eagle owls in size and distinct head tufts but are slimmer, lack feathered toes and tarsi, and fly noisily for owls. They glide slowly over water surfaces, catching prey with strong toes equipped with horny ridges and long claws.
image_alt: Malay Fish Owl, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 22–26 cm; tail length 16–18 cm; wingspan 120 cm; weight 1–1.2 kg
attractions: Formerly called fish owls, ketupas primarily hunt aquatic animals, from fish to crabs. They stay exclusively near calmer freshwater bodies. They glide slowly over water surfaces, catching prey with strong toes equipped with horny ridges and long claws. Sometimes they wade in shallows, collecting crabs or mollusks.
breeding: Ketupas were kept at the zoo from 1972–1993 and again since 2002, when a pair arrived from the wild. Greater expertise in their care is evidenced by the successful raising of a chick in 2009, symbolically named Evropa. Further breedings followed in 2010, 2012, and 2014.
